channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Whatever happened to ... the optimist who thinks games and music can change the world
item.description: On a planet that can feel increasingly challenged, we asked activist Edgard Gouveia Jr. about his latest efforts to improve life on Earth, what "artivism" is — and what he dreams of.
item.content:encoded:
On a planet that can feel increasingly challenged, we asked activist Edgard Gouveia Jr. about his latest efforts to improve life on Earth, what "artivism" is — and what he dreams of.

(Image credit: Marlena Waldhausen for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: ICE detains Kilmar Abrego Garcia again. And, Trump seeks to fire Fed governor
item.description: Kilmar Abrego Garcia has been taken into custody and faces deportation again, this time to Uganda. And, Trump seeks to fire a member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve.
item.content:encoded:
Kilmar Abrego Garcia has been taken into custody and faces deportation again, this time to Uganda. And, Trump seeks to fire a member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve.

(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: How plants and fungi trade resources without a brain
item.description: Fungi and plants have something to teach humans about global trade and cooperation
item.content:encoded:
Fungi and plants have something to teach humans about global trade and cooperation

(Image credit: Loreto Oyarte Gálvez)
item.dc:creator: Alex Mayyasi

item.title: A lesson learned after pets were left behind in Hurricane Katrina: Save the animals
item.description: People were forced to leave their pets behind during Hurricane Katrina, creating an unprecedented animal welfare crisis that has shaped the country's disaster response ever since.
item.content:encoded:
People were forced to leave their pets behind during Hurricane Katrina, creating an unprecedented animal welfare crisis that has shaped the country's disaster response ever since.

(Image credit: Chris Hondros)
item.dc:creator: Nathan Rott

item.title: 20 years after Hurricane Katrina, the Lower Ninth Ward in New Orleans still lags behind
item.description: No neighborhood was hit worse in Katrina than New Orleans' Lower Ninth Ward and it's been one of the slowest areas to rebound. There's still an effort to attract new residents and businesses there.
item.content:encoded:
No neighborhood was hit worse in Katrina than New Orleans' Lower Ninth Ward and it's been one of the slowest areas to rebound. There's still an effort to attract new residents and businesses there.

(Image credit: Claire Harbage)
item.dc:creator: Greg Allen

item.title: When hospitals and insurers fight, patients get caught in the middle
item.description: About 90,000 people spent months in limbo as central Missouri's major medical provider fought over insurance contracts. These disputes between insurers and hospitals are a recurring problem.
item.content:encoded:
About 90,000 people spent months in limbo as central Missouri's major medical provider fought over insurance contracts. These disputes between insurers and hospitals are a recurring problem.

(Image credit: Renata Hamuda/iStockphoto)
item.dc:creator: Bram Sable-Smith

item.title: Judge orders Kari Lake to answer questions about Voice of America under oath
item.description: U.S. Judge Royce Lamberth ordered Trump administration official Kari Lake to be deposed about her plans for Voice of America, saying she was on "verging on contempt."
item.content:encoded:
U.S. Judge Royce Lamberth ordered Trump administration official Kari Lake to be deposed about her plans for Voice of America, saying she was on "verging on contempt."

(Image credit: Joe Raedle)
item.dc:creator: David Folkenflik

item.title: A mom draws what it's like to have intrusive thoughts — and how to cope
item.description: After giving birth to her second child, NPR's LA Johnson struggled with scary thoughts that didn't seem to go away. She illustrates her experience in a comic, along with tips on how to cope.
item.content:encoded: After giving birth to her second child, NPR's LA Johnson struggled with scary thoughts that didn't seem to go away. She illustrates her experience in a comic, along with tips on how to cope.
item.dc:creator: LA Johnson

item.title: 'The most illegal search': Judges push back against D.C. criminal charges
item.description: Inside the federal courthouse in Washington, D.C., on Monday, tensions over the potential for federal overreach broke into open court.
item.content:encoded:
Inside the federal courthouse in Washington, D.C., on Monday, tensions over the potential for federal overreach broke into open court.

(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)
item.dc:creator: Carrie Johnson

item.title: ID lost to Hurricane Katrina is returned 20 years later
item.description: Twenty years after Hurricane Katrina crashed into Louisiana and Mississippi, surprises continue to surface. A washed-up ID and how a park ranger found its owner is a moment of joy in the tragedy.
item.content:encoded:
Twenty years after Hurricane Katrina crashed into Louisiana and Mississippi, surprises continue to surface. A washed-up ID and how a park ranger found its owner is a moment of joy in the tragedy.

(Image credit: Elizabeth Shadle)
item.dc:creator: Melanie Peeples
